questions.text: A study is conducted on the lungs to determine the lung response to injury. According to the study, right after inducing lethal damage to lung tissue, certain types of cells in the alveoli start proliferating and producing new cells that replace the damaged alveolar cells. These cells are most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
The alveoli are the major site of gas exchange in the lungs. They have thin walls with adjacent capillary vessels to allow for maximal exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the alveoli and red blood cells.  

The walls of the alveoli are made of 2 types of cells, i.e. type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes. Type 1 pneumocytes, which make up to 95% of the surface area of the alveoli, have a thin wall and a flat elongated nucleus. They are thin to allow maximal gas exchange. Type 2 pneumocytes, on the other hand, make up only around 5% of the surface area of the alveoli and are characterized by their cuboidal appearance. They have 2 major functions  

  1. They responsible for surfactant production  
  2. They are the regenerative cells for both type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes after pulmonary injury.  

The final type of cells that can be found in the alveoli are the alveolar macrophages. Alveolar macrophages act as defense cells and engulf any foreign particles that enter the alveoli.  


Option Analysis

✅ Type 2 pneumocytes  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 1 pneumocytes  :
Incorrect: Type 1 pneumocytes are not capable of regeneration and repair. Type 2 pneumocytes act as stem cells for both type 1 and 2 pneumocytes after alveolar injury.  
❌ Pulmonary macrophages  :
Incorrect: Pulmonary macrophages help in clearing the infection and debris but do not act as a stem cell precursor for alveolar pneumocytes  
❌ Goblet cells  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are not found in the alveoli, and they do not act as a stem cell precursor for pneumocytes.  
❌ Clara cells  :
Incorrect: Clara cells, also known as club cells, are only found in the bronchioles and are not present in the alveoli. These cells can act as a progenitor for club cells and epithelial cells in the bronchioles.

questions.text: A study is conducted on the respiratory system to determine the different cell types found in each portion of the respiratory system. A histological examination of the tracheal tissue was performed, and the image under microscope is shown below. Which of the following is true about the cells that are marked by the arrow?

choices.text: They are found in the trachea and bronchi only.
The concentration of these cells is higher in the bronchi than in the trachea
They function as regenerative cells for the epithelial cells
They extend from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles
They do not extend beyond the trachea

questions.solution:
The cells that are marked by the arrow are goblet cells that are only found in the trachea and bronchi in the respiratory tract. The trachea and bronchi are part of the conducting system of the respiratory tract, where they participate in conducting and modifying the inspired air (e.g. humidification) but do not participate in gas exchange.  

Both the trachea and bronchi have similar unique features that help distinguish them from other parts of the respiratory system. First of all, both have a cartilaginous component that does not extend beyond the bronchi. The cartilaginous component of the trachea is arranged into a C-shaped cartilaginous cap, and helps in supporting the trachea when different pressures are found in the lumen during inspiration and expiration.  

The cartilaginous component in the bronchi is less organized and is found surrounding the lumen with occasional gaps. The other histological feature that is unique to the trachea and bronchi is the presence of the goblet cells. These cells are found between the epithelial cells, and function to secrete mucus. They do not extend beyond the bronchi. Additionally, the concentration of goblet cells is the highest in the upper trachea and decreases as we move towards the lower trachea and further decreases in the bronchi.    


Option Analysis

✅ They are found in the trachea and bronchi only.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The concentration of these cells is higher in the bronchi than in the trachea  :
Incorrect: The goblet cells are less abundant in the bronchi than in the trachea. Also, they are less abundant in the lower trachea than in the upper trachea.
❌ They function as regenerative cells for the epithelial cells  :
Incorrect: The primary function of goblet cells is mucus secretion; they do not have stem cell properties.  
❌ They extend from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are only found in the trachea and bronchi, and do not extend beyond the bronchi.  
❌ They do not extend beyond the trachea  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are found in the trachea and bronchi.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. The symptoms developed shortly after he returned from an overseas business trip to Germany. Medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 148/89 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals clear, bilateral breath sounds. A D-dimer level returns elevated. Which of the following best characterizes the ventilation, perfusion, and V/Q ratio for the affected regions of this patient’s lungs?
questions.solution:
This patient has chest pain and an elevated D-dimer in the setting of recent long-distance travel, which is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The blood clot occludes vessels within the lungs, leading to decreased perfusion and a reduced V/Q ratio within affected portions of the lungs.

The V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q). Ventilation and perfusion matching are essential to achieving optimal gas exchange. Conditions that lead to airway obstruction (e.g., foreign body aspiration, bronchoconstriction) will decrease ventilation of the affected alveoli and lead to an increased V/Q ratio. In contrast, conditions that decrease blood flow (e.g. pulmonary embolism) will decrease perfusion and lead to an increased V/Q ratio.
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has a pulmonary embolism. The condition will reduce blood flow to affected portions of the lung, thereby causing the perfusion to decrease. Since perfusion decreases whereas ventilation remains largely unchanged, the ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio will increase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has a pulmonary embolism. The condition will reduce blood flow to affected portions of the lung, thereby causing a decrease in perfusion.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Conditions such as foreign body aspiration can lead to decreased ventilation, or gas exchange, within alveoli distal to the obstruction site. As a result, ventilation will decrease, and so will the V/Q ratio. However, this patient’s clinical history is more concerning for pulmonary embolism.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has chest pain and an elevated D-dimer in recent long-distance travel, which is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. The embolus occludes vessels within the lungs, leading to decreased perfusion of affected portions of the lungs.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the transport mechanisms of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) from peripheral tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream. According to his studies, there are multiple ways by which CO<sub>2</sub> is carried to the lungs. Which mechanisms are responsible for transporting most carbon dioxide from the tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream?

choices.text: CO2 In the form of HCO3

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary waste product produced by tissues and needs to be carried by the bloodstream to the lungs to get expelled from the body. There are three main mechanisms by which CO2 is transported through the blood:

1. Dissolved CO2 in the blood: Dissolved CO2 in the blood is one mechanism by which CO2 is carried to the lungs. However, this mechanism only accounts for around 3-5% of the total CO2 carried by the blood.

2. Bound to hemoglobin: In the peripheral tissues, abundant CO2 diffuses into red blood cells (RBCs) and gets attached to the hemoglobin at N-terminus (a different binding site than oxygen). When the CO2 binds to hemoglobin, it decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, thus causing oxygen to be released into the tissues. This phenomenon is termed the Bohr effect and is responsible for increased oxygen release into tissues with high CO2 concentration. This transport mechanism also accounts for a small fraction (3-5%) of the amount of CO2 carried in the blood.

3. In the form of HCO3-: When CO2 is abundant, it diffuses into RBCs. Within RBCs, CO2 reacts with H2O due to the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which catalyzes this reaction and produces hydrogen bicarbonate (H2CO3). H2CO3 is an unstable molecule that converts to H+ and HCO3-. H+ attaches to hemoglobin, forming H-Hb, while HCO3- is expelled outside the RBC in exchange for chloride (Cl-) ions. This form of transport accounts for most CO2 transported in the bloodstream.  

Option Analysis

✅ CO2 In the form of HCO3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CO2 bound to hemoglobin:
Incorrect: Carbaminohemoglobin (CO2 bound to hemoglobin) is one of the ways through which CO2 is transported to the lungs. However, this mechanism is responsible for transporting only a small proportion of CO2 in the blood.  
❌ CO2 dissolved in the blood:
Incorrect: Dissolved CO2 in the blood is one mechanism by which CO2 is carried to the lungs. However, this mechanism only accounts for around 3-5% of the total CO2 carried by the blood.  
❌ CO2 bound to albumin:
Incorrect: CO2 does not bind to albumin. This is not one of the mechanisms of transporting CO2 from the tissues to the lungs via the bloodstream.  
❌ CO2 dissolved in erythrocytes:
Incorrect: CO2 in erythrocytes, CO2 binds to hemoglobin or reacts with H2O to produce H+ and HCO3-.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the structure and function of hemoglobin. He discovers that certain conditions decrease oxygen unloading to tissues, as demonstrated in the graph below. Which of the following conditions favors this effect?

choices.text: Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2
Increasing the partial pressure of CO2

questions.solution:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve reflects the saturation of hemoglobin at different partial pressures of oxygen. Several conditions may result in either a left or right curve shift. A rightward shift indicates increasing oxygen unloading to tissues, where certain conditions decrease hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. In contrast, a leftward shift means decreasing oxygen unloading to tissues and a relative increase in affinity for oxygen. Conditions associated with either shift are reflected in the tables above.  


Option Analysis

✅ Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Incorrect: Increasing the partial pressure of CO2 will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ Increasing the temperature:
Incorrect:  Increasing the temperature will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ Decreasing the pH:
Incorrect: Decreasing the pH will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.  
❌ High altitude:
Incorrect: High altitude will result in a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after swallowing a small toy. Imaging is performed, revealing the toy is lodged within the right middle lobe bronchus. The patient’s partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO<sub>2</sub>) is 75 mmHg. Which of the following best characterizes the V/Q ratio in the affected portions of the lung and the effect that 100% supplemental oxygen administration would have on the patient’s PaO<sub>2</sub>?
questions.solution:
This patient was brought to the emergency department after aspirating a foreign object. The object has obstructed a bronchus, which will lead to decreased ventilation within the alveoli distal to the obstruction site. As a result, the V/Q ratio will decrease.

Furthermore, administering supplemental oxygen will not improve this patient’s partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2). This is a case of decreased ventilation that manifests with a decreased V/Q ratio. Supplemental oxygen cannot reach the obstructed alveoli to participate in gas exchange. Hence, the PaO2 will not increase.

In contrast, in perfusion defect (e.g. pulmonary embolism), which manifests with an increased V/Q ratio, supplemental oxygen will increase the PaO2. This is because oxygen can diffuse into the bloodstream via alveoli perfused by vessels not obstructed by the embolus.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus. As a result, affected portions of the right lung will have decreased ventilation and a decreased V/Q ratio, as opposed to an unchanged V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient has aspirated a foreign object that is obstructing the right middle lobe bronchus, which will lead to a decreased V/Q ratio within affected portions of the lung. However, administering supplemental oxygen will not improve the patient’s PaO2. This phenomenon exists since the supplemental oxygen will not be able to reach the obstructed alveoli to participate in gas exchange.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study is done to determine how carbon dioxide is transported through the bloodstream to the lungs. Two blood samples are examined, one in the peripheral tissues and one in the lungs. Which of the following findings is expected to be seen?

choices.text: Hemoglobin has a lower affinity for CO2 in the lungs
Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for CO2 in the lungs
Red blood cells (RBCs) in the lungs have higher chloride content
Hemoglobin has the same affinity for CO2 in both tissues
Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for H+ in the lungs

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is transported in the blood in three main forms: dissolved in the blood, bound to hemoglobin, and in the form of HCO3-.

When blood reaches the lungs, these mechanisms reverse to facilitate the expulsion of CO2.

When blood reaches the lungs, oxygen diffuses into the red blood cells and attaches to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules. This effect is termed the Haldane effect and helps in the reformation of free CO2. The CO2 released from the hemoglobin diffuses into the blood and the alveoli.

In addition, the release of H+ from hemoglobin causes HCO3- (the main form in which CO2 is carried in the bloodstream) to diffuse back into the RBC (in exchange for chloride). H+ and HCO3- are then joined together in the RBC cytoplasm by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase to make H2CO3, which quickly transforms into CO2 and H2O. CO2 then diffuses into the alveoli and gets exhaled.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hemoglobin has a lower affinity for CO2 in the lungs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for CO2 in the lungs:
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.  
❌ Red blood cells (RBCs) in the lungs have higher chloride content:
Incorrect: Since H+ is released from hemoglobin in the lungs, HCO3- diffuses into the RBC in exchange for chloride (Cl-). Therefore, the Cl- concentration in the RBCs is lower in the lungs than in peripheral tissues.  
❌ Hemoglobin has the same affinity for CO2 in both tissues  :
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.  
❌ Hemoglobin has a higher affinity for H+ in the lungs:
Incorrect: The high oxygen concentration in the lungs causes oxygen to bind to hemoglobin. This binding causes a change in the structure of hemoglobin and decreases its affinity for CO2 and H+, causing the release of both molecules.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is seen by a pulmonologist for exercise-related shortness of breath. The patient states that after 10 minutes of intense workout, he has to stop for at least 40 seconds to catch his breath. The patient has not had any episodes of fever, cough, or weight changes. A pulmonary function test is ordered and partial results are shown below. What is the functional residual capacity of this patient?
 
Tidal volume   
500 mL  
Residual volume
1200 mL  
Expiratory reserve volume   
1500 mL  
Inspiratory reserve volume  
3000 mL
questions.solution:
Certain lung volumes can be measured by spirometry. These physiologic lung volumes can be combined to determine certain capacities. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of gas in the lungs that is left after normal quiet expiration. It is a sum of expiratory reserve volume (air that can still be breathed out after normal expiration) and residual volume (air in the lungs after maximal expiration). In a normal, average-sized adult, the FRC is about 2500 mL. It is usually increased in patients with obstructive lung pathology (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) due to an increase in residual lung volume.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 5000 mL  :
Incorrect: Vital capacity is the maximum volume of gas that can be expired after a maximum inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, which, in this patient, is 5000 mL.  
✅ 2700 mL:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 3500 mL  :
Incorrect: Inspiratory capacity is the volume of gas that can be breathed in after normal exhalation. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume and tidal volume, which, in this patient, is 3500 mL.  
❌ 6200 mL:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity is the volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume, which, in this patient, is 6200 mL.  
❌ 300 mL  :
Incorrect: This measured volume is the difference between expiratory reserve volume and residual volume. This does not refer to any specific capacity.

questions.text: A medical student is conducting an experiment where he is using an air chamber submerged in water to determine the breathing mechanics of a normal human lung. He measures the volume of air that he can maximally inhale after a normal quiet expiration. Which of the following best describes this quantity of air?
questions.solution:
Normally, lungs provide oxygen to the blood after inhaling from the environment and then exhaling after gas exchange at the level of alveoli. Certain lung volumes can be measured by a spirometer (an air chamber submerged in water being the classic example) which are as follows:
   
  • Tidal Volume (TV): During normal, quiet breathing, the volume of air moving in and out with each breath is called the tidal volume; it’s typically around 500 mL. 
  • Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV): It is the maximum volume of air that can be breathed above the tidal volume and does not include the tidal volume; it is typically around 3000 mL. 
  • Expiratory reserve volume (ERV): It is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a normal quiet expiration. It is typically around 1200 mL 
  • Residual volume (RV): It is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. It is usually around 1200 mL 
Different physiologic lung volumes can be combined to determine certain capacities. Inspiratory capacity is the volume of gas that can be breathed in after normal exhalation. It is a sum of IRV and TV.  


Option Analysis

❌ Inspiratory reserve volume:
Incorrect: Inspiratory reserve volume is the volume of air that can be breathed above the tidal volume and does not include the tidal volume.  
❌ Tidal volume:
Incorrect: During normal, quiet breathing the volume of air moving in and out with each breath is called the tidal volume; it is typically around 500 ml.  
✅ Inspiratory capacity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vital capacity  :
Incorrect: Vital capacity is the maximum volume of gas that can be expired after a maximum inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume.  
❌ Total lung capacity:
Incorrect: Total lung capacity is the volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration. It is a sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of cyanotic episodes that occur when he is crying or running. The cyanosis tends to resolve when the patient squats down. Further workup is performed and the patient is diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot. Which of the following best characterizes the changes in pulmonary physiology that occur as a result of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot, which manifests as a right-to-left shunt and an elevated V/Q ratio.

A shunt occurs when blood flow is redirected from an expected route. Pulmonary shunts occur when deoxygenated blood passes from the right side of the heart to the left side without participating in gas exchange within the pulmonary capillaries. Given blood is diverted from the lungs, lung perfusion decreases whereas lung ventilation is grossly unchanged. As a result, pulmonary shunts are characterized by an increase in the ventilation-to-perfusion (V/Q) ratio.

Pulmonary shunts can be divided into physiological and pathological shunts. Physiological shunts include normal blood flow through the bronchial arteries (partially empties into pulmonary veins) and coronary arteries (partially empties into the left ventricle). In contrast, pathological shunts include tetralogy of Fallot and Eisenmenger syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt. Moreover, since blood is diverted away from the lungs, the condition leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and an increased V/Q ratio.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by pulmonary infundibular stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis leads to increased right ventricular outflow resistance. As a result, blood travels from the right ventricle to the left ventricle, thus manifesting as a right-to-left shunt. Moreover, since blood is diverted away from the lungs, the condition leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and an increased V/Q ratio.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The tetralogy of Fallot leads to blood being diverted away from the lungs. Thus, pulmonary blood flow is decreased and there is an increase (not decrease) in the V/Q ratio.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting an experiment on pulmonary physiology. He is studying differences in blood flow and ventilation in various regions of the lung when a patient is sitting upright. A diagram of the lung is shown below. Which of the following best describes the region of the lung with the highest V/Q ratio and the corresponding physiological significance?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 represents the lung apex and has adequate ventilation but poor perfusion, which limits gas exchange. Given these physiological characteristics, Zone 1 has the highest ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio.

When a patient is in the upright position, the lungs can be divided into three sections. These sections vary in blood flow, with greater blood flow in the gravity-dependent regions of the lung (e.g., lung base). In other words, at the lung apex, pulmonary arteriole pressure (Pa) and pulmonary venule pressure (Pv) are relatively low, at the lung base, Pa and Pv are relatively high, and in the middle of the lung, Pa and Pv are somewhere in between.

In Zone 1 alveolar pressure (PA) is higher than Pa and Pv. In this region, blood flow is inhibited because the arterioles are compressed by the relatively higher pressures in the nearby alveoli.

In Zone 2, PA is less than Pa but greater than Pv. However, since a pressure difference still exists between Pa and Pv, blood flow occurs. Zone 2 has a V/Q ratio less than that of Zone 1.

Finally, in Zone 3, PA is less than that of both Pa and Pv. Even though the pressure in the arterioles and venules exceeds that of the adjacent alveoli, the proteins and cells that constitute the alveolar wall are strong enough to resist collapsing. Among the different lung regions, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio.

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 1 corresponds to the lung apex. This region has the highest V/Q ratio given it receives adequate oxygenation but poor blood supply due to the fact that blood flow needs to act against gravity in trying to reach the superior aspects of the lung. In other words, oxygen in Zone 1 has difficulty diffusing into the bloodstream due to poor perfusion. As a result, there is wasted ventilation (not wasted perfusion).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 1 corresponds to the lung apex and has the highest V/Q ratio. In contrast, Zone 2 has a V/Q ratio less than that of Zone 1 but greater than that of Zone 3.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 3 corresponds to the lung base. This region receives extensive blood flow such that perfusion often exceeds ventilation. As a result, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio and wasted perfusion (not wasted ventilation).   
❌ :
Incorrect: Zone 3 corresponds to the lung base. This region receives extensive blood flow such that perfusion often exceeds ventilation. As a result, Zone 3 has the lowest V/Q ratio and wasted perfusion.
